Award.AwardTitle: Uncovering Regeneration-Permissive Cues in Lower Vertebrate Retina to Inform Retinal Regenerative Medicine

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1606128
Carrier, Rebecca L.

Retinal degeneration, particularly associated with aging, is a widespread and increasing health problem currently affecting 2.1 million people in the U.S. and imposing a substantial burden on the economy (~$2 billion annually). It is the leading cause of blindness worldwide. Cell transplantation strategies have shown tremendous promise, but are significantly limited by low levels of cell survival and integration (<1%). The proposed studies aim to elucidate the chemical and physical cues required to enable survival and integration of transplanted cells. This fundamental, quantitative understanding will provide a framework to guide future retinal regeneration strategies and design of materials to serve as effective cell delivery vehicles. The proposed project will also nurture a cohesive education plan including teaching and learning across education levels spanning from K-12 to postgraduate.

While the retinas of some lower vertebrate species do regenerate, the human retina does not. The role of lower vertebrate matrix composition, structure, and mechanical properties in tissue regeneration has not been explored, yet is likely significant and could be exploited to enable significant advances in regenerative medicine. The PI's recent preliminary results indicate that mammalian retinal progenitor cells display strikingly different behavior when introduced to the lower vertebrate (axolotl) retina, in a manner analogous to cell transplantation, relative to a mammalian retina. Specifically, the RPCs in the lower vertebrate retina exhibit markedly enhanced cell survival and integration into the retina - processes central to regeneration. This project will analyze the chemical and physical features of the lower vertebrate regeneration-permissive retinal microenvironment compared to that of adult mammalian retina. The research will include an in-depth study of human retinal progenitor cell response to lower vertebrate retinal matrix, including attachment, survival, differentiation and 3D migration, processes essential to successful cell transplantation strategies. The study will analyze cell response to both intact tissue and decellularized matrix, in the presence and absence of tissue-conditioned medium, to parse effects of cellular vs. acellular (matrix) components and soluble vs. insoluble cues. Importantly, an integrated systems-biology approach will quantitatively relate cell response to tissue/matrix/soluble factor cues and cell signaling events. This quantitative mechanistic understanding will provide a framework to guide future retinal regeneration strategies and biomaterial design.
This award by the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program of the CBET Division is co-funded by the Biomaterials Program of the Division of Materials Research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Retinal degeneration, particularly associated with aging, is a widespread and increasing health problem currently affecting 2.1 million people in the U.S. and imposing a substantial burden on the economy (~$2 billion annually). It is the leading cause of blindness worldwide. Cell transplantation strategies have shown tremendous promise, but are significantly limited by low levels of cell survival and integration. The overall research objective of the project is to elucidate regeneration-permissive cues of the lower vertebrate retinal microenvironment, to ultimately allow incorporation of such cues into retinal cell transplantation strategies, to enable survival and integration of transplanted retinal progenitor cells (RPC). The role of lower vertebrate microenvironment, i.e. cues provided by extracellular matrix (ECM), in tissue regeneration has not been explored, yet is likely significant and could be exploited to enable significant advances in regenerative medicine. The research goals include: 1. Isolation and comprehensive characterization of retinal ECM from species in which retinal regeneration does (axolotl) and does not (porcine) occur and 2. Investigate hRPC processes key to regeneration in response to regeneration permissive and non-permissive matrix microenvironments. Educational and outreach goals include: 1. development of graduate and undergraduate student research projects based on retinal ECM based biomaterial development and tissue engineering and 2. nurture a cohesive education plan including teaching and learning across education levels spanning from K-12 to postgraduate. 

Significant accomplishments included isolation and characterization of axolotl retina, as well as investigation of the impact of axolotl retinal ECM on retinal progenitor cell behavior in comparison to porcine retinal ECM. Axolotl retina was isolated and structurally and biochemically characterized in comparison to porcine retina, and determined to have similar layered structure and bulk composition (e.g., protein content, and concentrations of select growth factors). Isolated retinas were processed to obtain soluble factors, insoluble factors or decellularized matrix. Human RPCs were induced with porcine and axolotl retinal factors (both soluble and insoluble) and their attachment and cell proliferation were studied. Further, the survival, morphology and integration of porcine RPCs seeded onto whole retina in retinal explant cultures, in a manner mimicking cell transplantation, was characterized, using both standard fluorescence microscopy as well as light sheet microscopy (Fig 1). The axolotl retina presents cues that promote the attachment, survival, and integration of mammalian RPCs, while a mammalian (porcine) retina does not. 

Glycomics analyses were used to explore biochemical differences in the native and decellularized isolates of axolotl and porcine retina, as glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) are known to be important in development and regeneration. Glycomics analyses revealed significant differences in the distinctive sulfation pattern of chondroitin sulphate and spatial organization of hyaluronic acid in porcine and axolotl retina. These findings thus motivate further exploration of the role of these GAGs in regenerative processes, and potentially, in future projects, incorporation of these cues in regenerative therapy approaches. We also established a model of injury by retinectomy (physical removal of the retina)and subsequent retinal regeneration in the axolotl (Fig 2). This injury model will allow us to compare the compositionin the retinal microenvironment during regeneration to that in the quiescent state, for insight into cues that may be significant in regenerative processes. The retina was successfully removed through an incision in the sclera (accompanied by removal of the lens).We have shown that adult axolotl salamanders are capable of regenerating the retina after a retinectomy and established the regeneration timeline.

Educational and outreach outcomes: The research activities comprised the projects of several graduate  and undergraduate students, whose goals included analysis of cell response to retinal ECM materials and establishing a model of retinal injury to observe retinal regeneration. The research theme of biopolymers and their organization to form gels (as in certain ECMs) was incorporated into demonstrations of Chemical Engineering and Biology concepts for high school students considering careers in engineering and science through the Northeastern University Building Bridgesprogram and Summer Research Internprojects. The project team developed a workshop course module on ?Animal cell culture? and educational course modules on ?Stem cell tissue culture and organoids? for students of Northeastern University.
